history.content:
I took 16A, 61C, and 70 together and it was a difficult semester but I managed to get through. 16A is pretty easy if you pay attention in lecture and do the weekly homework. 61C doesn't have much workload compared to 61A and 61B but is really content heavy, and I struggled with it the most.

-------

If you take Math 110 then EE16A, ee16a will likely be a breeze because the class is split into three main modules: linear algebra, circuits, and the last is combining the two/fitting in very basic machine learning algorithms based on linear algebra. I'm currently taking EE16A and CS 61C right now.

EE16A has a problem set every week and the class is designed to help you complete the homework throughout the week(discussion Monday and Wednesdays, lecture Tuesday and Thursday, lab some time in the second half of the week, and hw due Friday) so if you get stuck on something, you have plenty of opportunities to get help. That is.. if you decide to start the homework early. I find myself taking about 5-10hours on the problem sets every week.

CS61C is very project based and the lectures are pretty dense because the class just has so much information packed in it. It's all really cool material though because you get to learn how a computer works on the lowest level. You turn your python into C, which is turned into RISC(an assembly language), which is turned into a bunch of 0 and 1s, which are then just "voltages" that you can put through timed circuits. That's just about a quarter of the class. Everything else includes a lot of parallelism, virtual memory, caches, and writing in C.

--

You'll definitely want to be comfortable with linear algebra before taking 184.

I took 16A, 61C, and 70 together and it was a difficult semester but I managed to get through. 16A is pretty easy if you pay attention in lecture and do the weekly homework. 61C doesn't have much workload compared to 61A and 61B but is really content heavy, and I struggled with it the most.

-------

EE16A has a problem set every week and the class is designed to help you complete the homework throughout the week(discussion Monday and Wednesdays, lecture Tuesday and Thursday, lab some time in the second half of the week, and hw due Friday) so if you get stuck on something, you have plenty of opportunities to get help. That is.. if you decide to start the homework early. I find myself taking about 5-10hours on the problem sets every week.

CS61C is very project based and the lectures are pretty dense because the class just has so much information packed in it. It's all really cool material though because you get to learn how a computer works on the lowest level. You turn your python into C, which is turned into RISC(an assembly language), which is turned into a bunch of 0 and 1s, which are then just "voltages" that you can put through timed circuits. That's just about a quarter of the class. Everything else includes a lot of parallelism, virtual memory, caches, and writing in C.

I took 16A, 61C, and 70 together and it was a difficult semester but I managed to get through. 16A is pretty easy if you pay attention in lecture and do the weekly homework. 61C doesn't have much workload compared to 61A and 61B but is really content heavy, and I struggled with it the most.

-------

I took 16A, 61C, and 70 together and it was a difficult semester but I managed to get through. 16A is pretty easy if you pay attention in lecture and do the weekly homework. 61C doesn't have much workload compared to 61A and 61B but is really content heavy, and I struggled with it the most.

children.subject:
For 184 -- Math 54 should be sufficient (at least, that's all I had when I took it, and felt it was fine, and I generally don't consider myself to be particularly strong re: math).

I would be wary of taking both 61C and 184 at the same time, as both are fairly project heavy courses. I didn't take them together (I took 61C at the same time as Math 54 and two heavy-ish breadths, and 184 at the same time as 170 and two heavy-ish breadths), but I think both 61C and 184 are somewhat relentless in their projects (as in, even if the projects themselves are not suuuuuper hard, they basically never end). 

Also unsure of your existing familiarity with C-style languages but that's also something you might be hit with pretty hard if you take both together.
In your opinion, how comparable are the projects in both classes to those in CS61B in terms of time?

In my opinion it’s kind of hard to compare these since there’s a lot of other variables that contribute to how much time you’ll have to spend on the projects or how much time you’ll want to spend on them.

But trying to generalize across what I’ve noticed/heard from others as well, maybe 61C and 184 are each 1.25-1.75 times as difficult?
Will Math 54 give me enough knowledge in linear algebra to do well?

history.content: Even if you haven't taken all of them, can I get a student opinion about the courseload for the ones you have taken? What did you struggle with the most and which I should prioritize studying over the break?
history.subject: EE16A, Math 110, CS61C, CS184 and breadth manageable?
